trial_identification.studytitle: Program to improve memory through exercise for people with dementia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A community-based physical exercise program to reduce functional decline in people with dementia: randomised controlled trial.

interventions.interventions: Four month home exercise program to be completed at least 3 times per week. The program comprises 10 simple exercises to be undertaken under the supervision of a carer.
interventions.comparator: Standard treatment - usual care and clinical management through the hospital's Memory Disorders Outpatient Clinic. This involves consultations with a physician regarding assessment, diagnosis, management and treatment as required and referrals to support services where necessary.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Cognitive function (Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale - cognitive subscale and Mini Mental State Examination).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Functional fitness (timed up and go, 10 metre walk, functional reach, sit to stand)
Other functioning (Barthels Activities of Daily Living, Geriatric depression scale, Pittsburgh sleep quality index, Neuropsychiatric Inventory, Clinician's Interview-Based Impression of Change-Plus)
Carer well-being (Zarit caregiver burden scale, SF-36: Short Form Health Survey 36)
Plasma levels (glucose, insulin, lipds, testosterone, sensitive C-reactive protein)

trial_design.concealment: Allocation following recruitment using sequentially numbered sealed opaque envelopes held by a person independent of the research team.

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: School of Human Life Sciences, University of Tasmania

othercollaborator.othercollaboratorname: School of Human Life Sciences, University of Tasmania

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The objective of the study is to assess the effectiveness of a community-based exercise program for people with dementia in reducing functional decline in the areas of cognitive, physical and behavioural functioning.
